choices.C: Create an exception in the vulnerability scanner, as the results and false positives and can be ignored safely
choices.B: Notify the application development team of the findings and advise management of the results
choices.D: Require that the application development team renews the farm certificate and includes a wildcard for the "˜local' domain in the certificate SAN field
choices.A: Advise the application development team that the SSL certificates on the backend servers should be revoked and reissued to match their hostnames

discussion.content:
shouldn't it be option A ?
"A. Advise the application development team that the SSL certificates on the backend servers should be revoked and reissued to match their hostnames"
https://www.manageengine.com/mobile-device-management/kb/ssl-certificate-name-mismatch.html
the hostname (backend1.local, backend2.local,..) is not matching with the one on the certificate (CN=farm.company.com), right?
Or maybe option D? "Require that the application development team renews the farm certificate and includes a wildcard for the "˜local' domain in the certificate SAN field"

comments.content:
I love both option A and D. But I'll have to go with option D and here's why? Take a closer look at the vulnerability scan result stating "SSL Expiration Less Than 90 Days".

Firstly, we do not know the exact day left till the actual expiry date of the certificate. The best practice is to avoid doing any last minute renewal, how can it be done, by renewing the certificate beforehand prior to the expired date.

Secondly, we also do know that requesting to renew the certificate will take up some time such as the Certificate Authority will have to approve your renew application and etc. before reissuing you your new certificate.

Thirdly, the question also did state "BEST addresses these finding", if you choose option A by revoking and reissuing to match the hostname, that will resolved your issue temporarily but you'll eventually have to go back to option D because you did not fix the problem of the expiring certificate.

Logically, you want to fix the root cause of the problem rather than the symptoms shown.

https://docs.digicert.com/manage-certificates/renew-ssltls-certificate/

Indeed option A is correct.

D is a possible, but from a security perspective it is less safe than issuing individual SSL certificates for each backend web server. 

Option A: If certificate is compromised it will be only compromised for one web server.
Option D: If a wildcard certificate is compromised, all your webservers are compromised.
https://www.packetlabs.net/wildcard-certificates/

questions.question_text:
A security analyst is running a routine vulnerability scan against a web farm. The farm consists of a single server acting as a load-balancing reverse proxy and offloads cryptographic processes to the backend servers. The backend servers consist of four servers that process the inquiries for the front end.
//IMG//

A web service SSL query of each server responds with the same output:
Connected (0x000003)
depth=0 /0=farm.company.com/CN=farm.company.com/OU=Domain Control Validated
Which of the following results BEST addresses these findings?

A cybersecurity analyst was asked to review several results of web vulnerability scan logs.
Given the following snippet of code:
//IMG//

Which of the following BEST describes the situation and recommendations to be made?

discussion.content:
Should be C

http://blog.unmaskparasites.com/2009/10/28/evolution-of-hidden-iframes/

Should be C. If 65.240.22.1 is malicious, it doesn't matter whether this iframe is visible or not. Simply visiting the web site will initiate a connection to the redirect site. Once the redirect is made, the exploit installs by leveraging a vulnerability in the user's browser or plug-in.

Ref: https://www.techrepublic.com/blog/it-security/uncloaking-invisible-iframes/

comments.content: Based on a google search of hidden iframes, all looks normal here. Looks like it was intended to be hidden. B is correct.
This can be a form of clickjacking where unknowing users are clicking on the hidden iframe. Since we're not sure this is legitimate, we should be on the side of caution.

The majority of malware identified by the Norton Secured Seal service will display in the "Malware requiring removal" section of the Malware tab in your Symantec Trust Center account. However, there are some instances when it may not be possible to display the specific location of the malware. This will require you to pay special attention to the identified Web pages and analyze them carefully. When analyzing your Web site for malware, pay attention to the following key identifiers:

Any code that opens 3rd party URLs
Uncommon or obscure JavaScript
Iframes that are set to "hidden" with dimensions set to zero
Iframes with a display status set to "none"
Note: Inline Frames (iframes) are windows cut into your Web page that allow your visitor to view another page on your site or off your site without reloading the entire page.

ref: https://knowledge.digicert.com/generalinformation/INFO1316.html

discussion.content: I think this is C.

choices.C: The security analyst has discovered an embedded iframe pointing to source IP 65.240.22.1 network. The link is hidden and suspicious. Recommend the entry be removed from the web page.
choices.A: The security analyst has discovered an embedded iframe pointing to source IP 65.240.22.1 network. The code should include the domain name. Recommend the entry be updated with the domain name.
choices.D: The security analyst has discovered an embedded iframe pointing to source IP 65.240.22.1 network. Recommend making the iframe visible. Fixing the code will correct the issue.
choices.B: The security analyst has discovered an embedded iframe that is hidden from users accessing the web page. This code is correct. This is a design preference, and no vulnerabilities are present.

choices.D: Servers have received different levels of attention during previous patch management events
choices.A: Servers have not been scanned with the latest vulnerability signature
choices.B: Servers have been attacked by outsiders using zero-day vulnerabilities
choices.C: Servers were made by different manufacturers

questions.question_text: A suite of three production servers that were originally configured identically underwent the same vulnerability scans. However, recent results revealed the three servers has different critical vulnerabilities. The servers are not accessible by the Internet, and AV programs have not detected any malware. The servers' syslog files do not show any unusual traffic since they were installed and are physically isolated in an off-site datacenter. Checksum testing of random executables does not reveal tampering. Which of the following scenarios is MOST likely?

comments.content: What did you choose? I think it's A

discussion.content: This question is on the exam.
Why this can't be C? it make more sense

questions.question_text: Malicious users utilized brute force to access a system. An analyst is investigating these attacks and recommends methods to management that would help secure the system. Which of the following controls should the analyst recommend? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
answer is correct. 
Question is saying "Malicious users utilized brute force to access a system" (...) "recommends methods to management that would help secure the system"
And asking: "Which of the following controls?"
A, E and F are correct.

MFA can be to get a code on the smartphone to approve (something you have)
Biometrics is "something you are". Can be fingerprint, retina scan, ...
Complexity policy will help to prevent the success brute force attack.
But on the question they are asking methods to "secure the system". So A,E,F

I think that ABE might be right.
https://nss.eu/xg-firewall-and-lateral-movement-protection/

How is biometrics automatically part of MFA? Lol
MFA has more options as well. Answer looks right. Not sure how segmentation resolves brute force
This question is on the exam.
Defense in-depth would include encryption...
I disagree. Network segmenting will not prevent brute force.... I also agree that biometrics and MFA are inclusive.. AFE is correct

comments.content: I can see i'm changing my mind from comment posted few days ago.. that's how confusing wording is. Now not sure to be honest what exactly the question is asking...

Not sure the question refers to methods to prevent brute force. Looks more like methods to increase security. As always CompTIA wording is confusing...

"and recommends methods to management that would help secure the system."

discussion.content: Agreed -- the answer is wrong. I'd say ABE too
A, B, and E? Biometrics is wrong as it won't help with preventing brute force

comments.content: and yes. Biometrics is included in MFA.

discussion.content: Surely Biometrics is already answered under MFA? Would it not be B instead of F? ABE?

comments.content:
Biometrics: Something you are and something you do include a biometric characteristic or any other trait inherent to the user such as handwriting or speech pattern.

In other words, checking behavior patterns after successful authentication can be used in "Active Authentication" where the user's activity is constantly - unbeknownst to the user - and compared to known behavior.

discussion.content: I believe NAC is correct. The question doesn’t say whether or not the remote host was authorized to be on the network. NAC is able to perform security checks on authorized remote hosts.
This question was in the exam :)
Network Access Control
NAC is the correct answer as it also offers to check the health of hosts by putting them in quarantine for remediation before re-joining the network.

The answer is NAC.
Some of the functions of NAC:
"Security posture check: Evaluates security-policy compliance by user type, device type, and operating system.
Incidence response: Mitigates network threats by enforcing security policies that block, isolate, and repair noncompliant machines without administrator attention."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-network-access-control-nac.html#~how-nac-works

firewalls/ACLs are typically placed on the perimeter of a network and control what goes in and out, while NACs are typically used for internal network user authentication. This one should be D. ACL.. google NIST 800-41 for better info.

comments.content: Holst NAC is used to authenticate devices as they join your network, check if your devices are running up to date software if not then it will quarantine the device, NAC can also be used for contextual authentication the answer here would be NAC.

From NIST 800-41: “Another common requirement for firewalls at the edge of a network is to perform client checks for incoming connections from remote users and allow or disallow access based on those checks. This checking, commonly called network access control (NAC) or network access protection (NAP), allows access based on the user’s credentials...”


“NAC has also become a popular method for firewalls to allow or deny users access to particular network resources. In addition, application firewalls and proxies can allow or deny access to users based on the user authentication within the applications themselves.”

discussion.content: Remote host-NAC would prevent access using location-based access?
This should be ACL and not NAC

questions.question_text: An incident response report indicates a virus was introduced through a remote host that was connected to corporate resources. A cybersecurity analyst has been asked for a recommendation to solve this issue. Which of the following should be applied?
